title: How to Disable Password Login on Mac (Plus Troubleshooting)

steps.title: Turn off FileVault.
steps.content: Turn off FileVault. If you're using FileVault to secure the data on your Mac's hard drive, you'll need to disable it before you can log in to your Mac without a password. Here's how: Click the Apple menu and select System Settings (or System Preferences on older versions of macOS). [1] X Research source Go to Privacy & Security > FileVault . Click Turn Off and then Turn Off Encryption.

steps.title: Open System Settings.
steps.content: Open System Settings. If you're using macOS Ventura or later, click the Apple menu and select System Settings . On Monterey and earlier, click the Apple menu and select System Preferences . [2] X Research source

steps.title: Click Users & Groups in the left panel.
steps.content: Click Users & Groups in the left panel. If you're using macOS Monterey or earlier, click Login Options on the left, then click the padlock to enter your password.

steps.title: Select your account from the "Automatically log in as" menu.
steps.content: Select your account from the "Automatically log in as" menu. It's on the right panel. If the account is dimmed out, see the Troubleshooting section.

steps.title: Enter your user account password.
steps.content: Enter your user account password. Once verified, this account will be able to log in to macOS without a password. You might be asked to log in manually after logging out of the account, locking your screen , or switching from another user account.

steps.title: I can't select my account from the "Automatically log in as" menu.
steps.content: I can't select my account from the "Automatically log in as" menu. This menu is grayed out you haven't disabled FileVault, an administrator has turned off automatic logins, or you're using your iCloud password to log in to your Mac. If you're using your iCloud password , you may see the error A user with an encrypted home folder can't log in automatically . [3] X Research source To fix this, you'll need to change your Mac's login password to something unique. [4] X Research source Click the Apple menu and go to System Settings > Users & Groups . Click the info icon (the small i in a circle) next to your username and select Change . Enter your current password, and then enter a new one just for logging in to your Mac. Click Change Password to confirm. [5] X Research source

steps.title: I still have to enter a password when I wake my Mac.
steps.content: I still have to enter a password when I wake my Mac. If you don't want your Mac to ask for a password after sleep or the screen saver begins, you can change this in your Lock Screen settings. Here's how: Click the Apple menu and select System Settings . Click Lock Screen in the sidebar. [6] X Research source If you're using Monterey or earlier, select Security & Privacy instead. Click the menu next to "Require password after screen saver begins or display is turned off" and select Never . Or, if you're using Monterey or earlier, remove the checkmark from "Require password" and enter your password if prompted.
